user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_tell:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_dir_tell(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir);

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_dir_tell_(lfs, dir);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_tell:
static lfs_soff_t lfs_dir_tell_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    (void)lfs;
    return dir->pos;
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided snippets use any of the <string.h> functions named in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). The functions/macros shown are:
- lfs_dir_tell: calls LFS_LOCK, LFS_TRACE, lfs_dir_tell_, LFS_UNLOCK and returns the result — none are string functions.
- lfs_dir_tell_: casts away an unused parameter and returns dir->pos; this is a simple member access, not a string operation.
- LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE macros: their definitions do not call any string handling functions (LFS_TRACE is empty here; LFS_LOCK/UNLOCK only use (void)cfg and integer/void expressions).

Because no string.h APIs are invoked and there are no calls that pass pointers/buffers to such functions in the provided code, there is nothing that needs investigation under Rule 21.17 in these snippets. If other parts of the codebase (not provided) call string.h functions, those call sites should be inspected for buffer bounds, but no such call sites exist in the given code.
